semantic_title: Integral Signs and Symptoms Should Not Be Coded Separately
section_path: Section I > B. General Coding Guidelines > 5. Conditions that are an integral part of a disease process

content.full_text: Signs and symptoms that are associated routinely with a disease process should not be assigned as additional codes, unless otherwise instructed by the classification. (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
content.summary: Prohibits coding signs and symptoms that are routinely associated with a disease process as additional codes, unless specifically instructed otherwise by ICD-10-CM. (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
key_concepts: Integral symptoms should not be coded separately (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
Routine association with disease process determines integrality (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
Classification instructions can override this rule (Evidence: pg no: 13, L44)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Do not assign additional codes for signs/symptoms routinely associated with disease (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
detailed_rules.explanation: When signs and symptoms are typically expected and routinely occur as part of a disease process, they should not be coded separately as additional diagnoses because they are considered integral to the disease itself (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
common_applications: Shortness of breath with congestive heart failure

detailed_rules.rule_text: Classification instructions can override the integral symptom rule (Evidence: pg no: 13, L44)
detailed_rules.explanation: Even if a symptom is typically integral to a disease, if the ICD-10-CM classification specifically instructs to code it additionally (through 'use additional code' notes or similar), then it should be coded (Evidence: pg no: 13, L44)
common_applications: Specific classification guidance overriding general rules

workflow_steps: Step 3: Determine if symptoms are routinely associated with the disease
Step 4: Check for any classification instructions requiring additional coding
Step 5: Code only non-integral symptoms or those specifically instructed

references_to.title: Conditions that are not an integral part of a disease process
references_to.explanation: Contrasts with conditions that should be coded when not integral

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient diagnosed with pneumonia and fever
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Final diagnosis: Community-acquired pneumonia with fever
step_by_step: Step 3: Determine fever is routinely associated with pneumonia
Step 4: Check for classification instructions (none requiring fever code)
Step 5: Code only pneumonia, not fever separately

correct_coding.rationale: Fever is integral to pneumonia and should not be coded separately (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Fever is integral to pneumonia and should not be coded additionally
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Coding integral symptoms as additional diagnoses

warnings: Do not code symptoms that are routinely part of the disease process (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
best_practices: Always check if symptoms are integral before coding separately (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
Look for classification instructions that may override this rule (Evidence: pg no: 13, L44)
common_mistakes: Coding fever with infections when fever is expected (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
Coding chest pain with myocardial infarction (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
tips: Consider whether the symptom is expected with the disease (Evidence: pg no: 13, L43-L44)
Check tabular list for any 'use additional code' instructions (Evidence: pg no: 13, L44)
implementation_notes: Requires clinical knowledge of disease processes
